learning_outcomes.description: Discuss and interpret the importance of symmetry in the development of theories in mathematical physics.
Explain how algebraic structures provide the mathematical framework to describe symmetries
Understand the continuum limit of lattice models that leads to (quantum and statistical) field theories.
Employ renormalisation techniques in field theories and understand universal features of critical phenomena.
Apply and evaluate appropriate methods for the analysis of various classical and quantum systems in mathematical physics.

assessments.task_description: The four assignments are equally weighted. Each student is to submit their own solutions by the due date and time.
assessments.submission_guidelines: All assignments have to be submitted exclusively in digital form on blackboard.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.due_date:
15/09/2025 - 26/09/2025

Confirmation of the date, time, and venue will be communicated to students by the end of week 3 of the semester.Â
assessments.task_description:
The In-Semester exam in this course will be held between weeks 8 and 9. It will be an outside class time in-person exam held on campus.

The In-Semester exam will be comprehensive, with all material covered in the lectures and applied classes up to week 7 being examinable. Any excluded topics will be advised via Blackboard.

The In-Semester exam will be a 90-minute-long, open-book exam. No calculators or other aids allowed.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description:
The end-of-semester exam in this course will be held during the end-of-semester examination period. It will be an in-person exam held on campus.

The end-of-semester exam will be based on the content of the second part of the course only (Week 7 - Week 13).

During this written exam, answer all questions. Keep in mind that the marks associated with each part of a question are not necessarily an indication of how much time they will take to answer. Try to attempt all parts of each question in order to maximise your marks. If you find yourself spending too long on one particular question, explain how you think your answer should proceed, and move on.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.topic:
Lectures

Lectures by A/Prof Jon LINKS and Dr Gabriele TARTAGLINO MAZZUCCHELLI
learning_activities.topic_description: Lectures Lectures by A/Prof Jon LINKS and Dr Gabriele TARTAGLINO MAZZUCCHELLI

learning_activities.topic:
Applied Classes

There will be one applied class per week to work on assignments and discuss course content.

The first 7 weeks will have allocated a separate tutor. In the second part of the course, Dr Tartaglino Mazzucchelli will merge lectures and applied classes, recommending an interactive environment in the class.
